trailingComments.value:
*
 * The `PostStreamScrubber` component displays a scrubber which can be used to
 * navigate/scrub through a post stream.
 *
 * ### Props
 *
 * - `stream`
 * - `className`

*
     * The index of the post that is currently at the top of the viewport.
     *
     * @type {Number}

     * The number of posts that are currently visible in the viewport.

trailingComments.value: When the post stream begins loading posts at a certain index, we want our
scrubber scrollbar to jump to that position.

leadingComments.value: When the post stream begins loading posts at a certain index, we want our
scrubber scrollbar to jump to that position.

trailingComments.value: Define a handler to update the state of the scrollbar to reflect the
current scroll position of the page.

leadingComments.value: Define a handler to update the state of the scrollbar to reflect the
current scroll position of the page.

trailingComments.value: Create a subtree retainer that will always cache the subtree after the
initial draw. We render parts of the scrubber using this because we
modify their DOM directly, and do not want Mithril messing around with
our changes.

leadingComments.value: Create a subtree retainer that will always cache the subtree after the
initial draw. We render parts of the scrubber using this because we
modify their DOM directly, and do not want Mithril messing around with
our changes.

*
   * When the page is scrolled, update the scrollbar to reflect the visible
   * posts.

trailingComments.value:
*
   * Update the index/visible/description properties according to the window's
   * current scroll position.
   *
   * @param {Integer} scrollTop
Before looping through all of the posts, we reset the scrollbar
properties to a 'default' state. These values reflect what would be
seen if the browser were scrolled right up to the top of the page,
and the viewport had a height of 0.

leadingComments.value: Before looping through all of the posts, we reset the scrollbar
properties to a 'default' state. These values reflect what would be
seen if the browser were scrolled right up to the top of the page,
and the viewport had a height of 0.

trailingComments.value: Now loop through each of the items in the discussion. An 'item' is
either a single post or a 'gap' of one or more posts that haven't
been loaded yet.
If this item is above the top of the viewport, skip to the next
one. If it's below the bottom of the viewport, break out of the
loop.

leadingComments.value: If this item is above the top of the viewport, skip to the next
one. If it's below the bottom of the viewport, break out of the
loop.

trailingComments.value: Work out how many pixels of this item are visible inside the viewport.
Then add the proportion of this item's total height to the index.

leadingComments.value: Work out how many pixels of this item are visible inside the viewport.
Then add the proportion of this item's total height to the index.

trailingComments.value: If this item has a time associated with it, then set the
scrollbar's current period to a formatted version of this time.

leadingComments.value: If this item has a time associated with it, then set the
scrollbar's current period to a formatted version of this time.
Now loop through each of the items in the discussion. An 'item' is
either a single post or a 'gap' of one or more posts that haven't
been loaded yet.

*
   * Update the index/visible/description properties according to the window's
   * current scroll position.
   *
   * @param {Integer} scrollTop

trailingComments.value: Whenever the window is resized, adjust the height of the scrollbar
so that it fills the height of the sidebar.

leadingComments.value: Whenever the window is resized, adjust the height of the scrollbar
so that it fills the height of the sidebar.

trailingComments.value: When any part of the whole scrollbar is clicked, we want to jump to
that position.
Now we want to make the scrollbar handle draggable. Let's start by
preventing default browser events from messing things up.

leadingComments.value: Now we want to make the scrollbar handle draggable. Let's start by
preventing default browser events from messing things up.
When any part of the whole scrollbar is clicked, we want to jump to
that position.

trailingComments.value: When the mouse is pressed on the scrollbar handle, we capture some
information about its current position. We will store this
information in an object and pass it on to the document's
mousemove/mouseup events later.

leadingComments.value: When the mouse is pressed on the scrollbar handle, we capture some
information about its current position. We will store this
information in an object and pass it on to the document's
mousemove/mouseup events later.

trailingComments.value: Exempt the scrollbar handle from the 'jump to' click event.

leadingComments.value: Exempt the scrollbar handle from the 'jump to' click event.

trailingComments.value: When the mouse moves and when it is released, we pass the
information that we captured when the mouse was first pressed onto
some event handlers. These handlers will move the scrollbar/stream-
content as appropriate.

leadingComments.value: When the mouse moves and when it is released, we pass the
information that we captured when the mouse was first pressed onto
some event handlers. These handlers will move the scrollbar/stream-
content as appropriate.

trailingComments.value:
*
   * Update the scrollbar's position to reflect the current values of the
   * index/visible properties.
   *
   * @param {Boolean} animate
jQuery likes to put overflow:hidden, but because the scrollbar handle
has a negative margin-left, we need to override.

leadingComments.value: jQuery likes to put overflow:hidden, but because the scrollbar handle
has a negative margin-left, we need to override.

*
   * Update the scrollbar's position to reflect the current values of the
   * index/visible properties.
   *
   * @param {Boolean} animate

trailingComments.value:
*
   * Get the percentage of the height of the scrubber that should be allocated
   * to each post.
   *
   * @return {Object}
   * @property {Number} index The percent per post for posts on either side of
   *     the visible part of the scrubber.
   * @property {Number} visible The percent per post for the visible part of the
   *     scrubber.
To stop the handle of the scrollbar from getting too small when there
are many posts, we define a minimum percentage height for the handle
calculated from a 50 pixel limit. From this, we can calculate the
minimum percentage per visible post. If this is greater than the actual
percentage per post, then we need to adjust the 'before' percentage to
account for it.

leadingComments.value: To stop the handle of the scrollbar from getting too small when there
are many posts, we define a minimum percentage height for the handle
calculated from a 50 pixel limit. From this, we can calculate the
minimum percentage per visible post. If this is greater than the actual
percentage per post, then we need to adjust the 'before' percentage to
account for it.

*
   * Get the percentage of the height of the scrubber that should be allocated
   * to each post.
   *
   * @return {Object}
   * @property {Number} index The percent per post for posts on either side of
   *     the visible part of the scrubber.
   * @property {Number} visible The percent per post for the visible part of the
   *     scrubber.

trailingComments.value: Adjust the height of the scrollbar so that it fills the height of
the sidebar and doesn't overlap the footer.

leadingComments.value: Adjust the height of the scrollbar so that it fills the height of
the sidebar and doesn't overlap the footer.

trailingComments.value: Work out how much the mouse has moved by - first in pixels, then
convert it to a percentage of the scrollbar's height, and then
finally convert it into an index. Add this delta index onto
the index at which the drag was started, and then scroll there.

leadingComments.value: Work out how much the mouse has moved by - first in pixels, then
convert it to a percentage of the scrollbar's height, and then
finally convert it into an index. Add this delta index onto
the index at which the drag was started, and then scroll there.

trailingComments.value: If the index we've landed on is in a gap, then tell the stream-
content that we want to load those posts.

leadingComments.value: If the index we've landed on is in a gap, then tell the stream-
content that we want to load those posts.
Calculate the index which we want to jump to based on the click position.
1. Get the offset of the click from the top of the scrollbar, as a
percentage of the scrollbar's height.

trailingComments.value: 2. We want the handle of the scrollbar to end up centered on the click
position. Thus, we calculate the height of the handle in percent and
use that to find a new offset percentage.

leadingComments.value: 2. We want the handle of the scrollbar to end up centered on the click
position. Thus, we calculate the height of the handle in percent and
use that to find a new offset percentage.

trailingComments.value: 3. Now we can convert the percentage into an index, and tell the stream-
content component to jump to that index.

leadingComments.value: 3. Now we can convert the percentage into an index, and tell the stream-
content component to jump to that index.

*
 * The `PostStreamScrubber` component displays a scrubber which can be used to
 * navigate/scrub through a post stream.
 *
 * ### Props
 *
 * - `stream`
 * - `className`

*
 * The `PostStreamScrubber` component displays a scrubber which can be used to
 * navigate/scrub through a post stream.
 *
 * ### Props
 *
 * - `stream`
 * - `className`

comments.value:
*
 * The `PostStreamScrubber` component displays a scrubber which can be used to
 * navigate/scrub through a post stream.
 *
 * ### Props
 *
 * - `stream`
 * - `className`

*
     * The index of the post that is currently at the top of the viewport.
     *
     * @type {Number}

*
     * The number of posts that are currently visible in the viewport.
     *
     * @type {Number}

*
     * The description to render on the scrubber.
     *
     * @type {String}
When the post stream begins loading posts at a certain index, we want our
scrubber scrollbar to jump to that position.
Define a handler to update the state of the scrollbar to reflect the
current scroll position of the page.
Create a subtree retainer that will always cache the subtree after the
initial draw. We render parts of the scrubber using this because we
modify their DOM directly, and do not want Mithril messing around with
our changes.

*
   * Go to the first post in the discussion.

*
   * Go to the last post in the discussion.

*
   * Get the number of posts in the discussion.
   *
   * @return {Integer}

*
   * When the stream is unpaused, update the scrubber to reflect its position.

*
   * Check whether or not the scrubber should be disabled, i.e. if all of the
   * posts are visible in the viewport.
   *
   * @return {Boolean}

*
   * When the page is scrolled, update the scrollbar to reflect the visible
   * posts.
   *
   * @param {Integer} top

*
   * Update the index/visible/description properties according to the window's
   * current scroll position.
   *
   * @param {Integer} scrollTop
Before looping through all of the posts, we reset the scrollbar
properties to a 'default' state. These values reflect what would be
seen if the browser were scrolled right up to the top of the page,
and the viewport had a height of 0.
Now loop through each of the items in the discussion. An 'item' is
either a single post or a 'gap' of one or more posts that haven't
been loaded yet.
If this item is above the top of the viewport, skip to the next
one. If it's below the bottom of the viewport, break out of the
loop.
Work out how many pixels of this item are visible inside the viewport.
Then add the proportion of this item's total height to the index.
If this item has a time associated with it, then set the
scrollbar's current period to a formatted version of this time.
Whenever the window is resized, adjust the height of the scrollbar
so that it fills the height of the sidebar.
When any part of the whole scrollbar is clicked, we want to jump to
that position.
Now we want to make the scrollbar handle draggable. Let's start by
preventing default browser events from messing things up.
When the mouse is pressed on the scrollbar handle, we capture some
information about its current position. We will store this
information in an object and pass it on to the document's
mousemove/mouseup events later.
Exempt the scrollbar handle from the 'jump to' click event.
When the mouse moves and when it is released, we pass the
information that we captured when the mouse was first pressed onto
some event handlers. These handlers will move the scrollbar/stream-
content as appropriate.

*
   * Update the scrollbar's position to reflect the current values of the
   * index/visible properties.
   *
   * @param {Boolean} animate
jQuery likes to put overflow:hidden, but because the scrollbar handle
has a negative margin-left, we need to override.

*
   * Get the percentage of the height of the scrubber that should be allocated
   * to each post.
   *
   * @return {Object}
   * @property {Number} index The percent per post for posts on either side of
   *     the visible part of the scrubber.
   * @property {Number} visible The percent per post for the visible part of the
   *     scrubber.
To stop the handle of the scrollbar from getting too small when there
are many posts, we define a minimum percentage height for the handle
calculated from a 50 pixel limit. From this, we can calculate the
minimum percentage per visible post. If this is greater than the actual
percentage per post, then we need to adjust the 'before' percentage to
account for it.
Adjust the height of the scrollbar so that it fills the height of
the sidebar and doesn't overlap the footer.
Work out how much the mouse has moved by - first in pixels, then
convert it to a percentage of the scrollbar's height, and then
finally convert it into an index. Add this delta index onto
the index at which the drag was started, and then scroll there.
If the index we've landed on is in a gap, then tell the stream-
content that we want to load those posts.
Calculate the index which we want to jump to based on the click position.
1. Get the offset of the click from the top of the scrollbar, as a
percentage of the scrollbar's height.
2. We want the handle of the scrollbar to end up centered on the click
position. Thus, we calculate the height of the handle in percent and
use that to find a new offset percentage.
3. Now we can convert the percentage into an index, and tell the stream-
content component to jump to that index.
